metadata.title: Convert Kilowatts to Horsepower – Power Converter
metadata.description: Convert power from kilowatts (kW) to horsepower (hp) using the exact conversion factor, ideal for motor specifications, automotive performance, and industrial equipment ratings.

introduction: This converter transforms power measurements from kilowatts (kW) to horsepower (hp), bridging metric and imperial power standards. It is designed for engineers, automotive professionals, and equipment technicians who work with mixed power specifications across motor nameplates, equipment ratings, and performance documentation.

The kilowatt is the SI metric standard for power, while horsepower remains common in North American automotive, industrial, and legacy equipment specifications. Understanding this conversion is essential for motor selection, equipment compatibility, and performance comparisons.

The converter applies the exact, mathematically derived relationship between the watt (SI base unit) and the mechanical horsepower, ensuring reliable results for all power system applications and technical documentation.
methodology: The kilowatt (kW) is a unit of power equal to 1,000 watts, where the watt is the SI base unit defined as one joule per second (J/s). Horsepower is defined as 745.7 watts, derived from the historical definition of the rate at which a horse could perform work. The exact relationship is: 1 kW = 1.34102 hp (or equivalently, 1 hp = 0.745700 kW).

To convert a power value from kilowatts to horsepower, you divide the kilowatt value by 0.745700 (or multiply by 1.34102). For example, 10 kW = 13.41 hp, 50 kW = 67.05 hp, and 100 kW = 134.10 hp. This conversion is used consistently in motor specifications, automotive performance data, and industrial power ratings worldwide.

The converter applies full-precision floating-point arithmetic internally to maintain maximum accuracy. Results are displayed rounded to practical precision (typically two to three decimal places), suitable for equipment nameplates, performance specifications, and technical documentation.

Because the conversion factor is exact and standardized, this converter produces results consistent with IEEE standards for electrical machinery, automotive industry specifications (SAE), and international equipment labeling requirements.
examples: Example 1 – Electric motor: A typical industrial electric motor rated at 22 kW converts to approximately 29.51 hp, a common motor specification for compressors and machinery.
Example 2 – Automotive engine: A modern car engine producing 74.57 kW converts to 100 hp, demonstrating the exact definition of mechanical horsepower.
Example 3 – High-power equipment: A large pump or compressor rated at 150 kW converts to approximately 201.15 hp, typical for heavy industrial applications.
Example 4 – Renewable energy: A wind turbine generator producing 2,000 kW (2 MW) converts to approximately 2,682.04 hp, illustrating large-scale power conversion.

faqs.question: What is the exact conversion from kilowatts to horsepower?
faqs.answer: The exact factor is 1 kW = 1.34102 hp. To convert any power in kW to hp, divide by 0.745700 or multiply by 1.34102. This factor is derived from the SI definition of the watt and the standardized definition of mechanical horsepower (745.7 W).

faqs.question: Why do motor nameplates show both kilowatts and horsepower?
faqs.answer: Motors sold in different regions use different standards: metric countries use kilowatts, while North American equipment uses horsepower. Many modern motors are labeled with both units for international compatibility and ease of equipment selection across markets.

faqs.question: How do I quickly estimate kW to horsepower?
faqs.answer: A useful approximation is to multiply kW by 1.34 to get a rough hp value. For example, 50 kW × 1.34 = 67 hp (actual: 67.05 hp), accurate to within about 0.1%. This mental math is practical for equipment comparison.

faqs.question: Is this conversion exact enough for motor selection?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor 1.34102 is the standard used by motor manufacturers, IEEE electrical standards, and equipment engineers worldwide. When selecting motors or comparing equipment across regions, this exact factor ensures your work aligns with international standards.

faqs.question: What precision should I use for power specifications?
faqs.answer: For most equipment nameplates and technical work, two decimal places are sufficient. For detailed engineering calculations or formal specifications, maintain three significant figures (e.g., 22 kW = 29.5 hp). Always follow your equipment manufacturer's documentation for required precision.

faqs.question: Can I use this converter for electrical and mechanical power?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor applies equally to electrical power (measured in kilowatts of electrical generation or consumption) and mechanical power (measured in hp of motor output). The relationship is consistent across both domains.

faqs.question: How do automotive power ratings compare between kW and hp?
faqs.answer: Automotive manufacturers list engine power in either kW (metric markets) or hp (North American markets). A 100 hp engine produces 74.57 kW, while a 100 kW engine produces 134.1 hp. This converter ensures you can accurately compare performance specs across vehicles from different regions.

faqs.question: Why is mechanical horsepower (hp) equal to 745.7 watts?
faqs.answer: The definition originates from the historical work of James Watt, who defined horsepower as the rate at which a horse could lift 550 pounds one foot high in one second. In metric units, this equals 745.7 watts. This definition is standardized internationally as mechanical horsepower or 'hp' in most equipment specifications.

glossary.definition: A metric unit of power equal to 1,000 watts. The standard power unit in SI and used in international equipment specifications, electrical systems, and renewable energy applications.
An imperial unit of power equal to 745.7 watts. Historically defined as the work rate of a horse and remains standard in North American automotive, industrial, and legacy equipment specifications.
The SI base unit of power, equal to one joule per second (J/s). One kilowatt equals 1,000 watts. The watt is the foundation of all SI power measurements.
Power associated with physical motion, work, or machinery. Measured in kilowatts (metric) or horsepower (imperial). Used in motor ratings, automotive performance, and equipment specifications.
Power associated with electrical current and voltage. Measured in kilowatts (metric) or horsepower-equivalents (imperial). Used in electrical system ratings and utility measurements.
